description:
These resources can be used to manage and execute queries. The endpoint of these resources is based on your project name. For instance, if your 28.io project is named myproject, your endpoint for this API will be will be: http://myproject.28.io/v1/_queries.

A token needs to be provided to methods that require authentication. A token can be given in one of the following ways, ordered by priority:

  1. X-28msec-Token header;
  2. _token query parameter;
  3. token query parameter.

operations.notes: This method retrieves a list of queries that belong to a project. To only list public (resp. private) queries set the visibility parameter to public (resp. private). To list both public and private queries, omit the visibility parameter.

responseMessages.message: Bad request: a parameter is missing or invalid.
Unauthorized: the specified project token is invalid or expired.
An internal error occurred during the processing of the request.

examples.title: Listing all queries
examples.description: The following request retrieves the list of all queries associated with the project named myproject.

operations.notes:
This method executes a non-side-effecting query and serialize its results using a chosen serialization method. The following serialization methods are available: JSON-XML-hybrid, JSON, XML, Text, HTML, and XHTML.

It is also possible to use the 28.io serialization method. The 28.io serialization produces a JSON object with metadata about the items produced as query result. This serialization method format is unstable and will be documented as soon we are ready to commit to backward compatibility.

The HTTP response of this method is using streaming. Therefore, if an error occurs after part of the response has already been sent to the client, the response status code will be 200. In this case, the streaming of the HTTP response will stop and the following string will be sent "\n\n\nAn error occurred during the processing of the request.\n" followed by the error description. To always get a well-formed JSON error response, and the expected HTTP error status code, it is possible to issue the same request using POST. Note however that, in this case, the HTTP response will not stream.

Query Serialization

The serialization method can be chosen by means of the Accept header or by specifying the format parameter. In case no serialization method is specified, JSON-XML-hybrid is used.

Specifically, the serialization method is chosen as follows:

  1. if an Accept header is specified and if it contains at least one supported mime-type/charset pair, the serialization method corresponding to the most preferred one (according to the "q" modifier first and the order in which the mime-types are specified second) among those supported is chosen;
  2. otherwise, if a format parameter is specified, the corresponding serialization method is chosen;
  3. otherwise, JSON-XML-hybrid is used.

If the Accept header is specified and it contains at least one supported mime-type, the preferred supported mime-type is used to choose the serialization method, according to the following mapping:

  • application/mixed-json-xml: JSON-XML-hybrid Serialization
  • application/json or any mime-type which ends with +json: JSON Serialization
  • text/xml, application/xml or any mime-type which ends with +xml: XML Serialization
  • text/html: HTML Serialization
  • application/xhtml+xml: XHTML Serialization
  • application/28io+json: 28.io Serialization (format definition unstable)
  • * / *: the Accept header is ignored and the format parameter, if specified, is used to choose the serialization method.

Any mime-type not matching one of the conditions listed above is not supported by this resource.

If the format parameter has been specified and is used to choose the serialization method, the following mapping is used:

  • .mixed: JSON-XML-hybrid Serialization
  • .json: JSON Serialization
  • .xml: XML Serialization
  • .text: Text Serialization
  • .html: HTML Serialization
  • .xhtml: XHTML Serialization
  • .28io-json: 28.io Serialization (format definition unstable).

Response Content-Type and Encoding

The content-type of the response is determined as follows:

  1. If the serialization method has been chosen depending on one of the mime-types specified in the Accept header, the following criterion are used:
    • if the used mime-type is * / * or application/mixed-json-xml then the response content type depends on the first item of the result. If it is an XML node the response content-type will be application/xml, otherwise application/json
    • for any other mime-type, the same mime-type is used in the response.
    In case no charset has been specified for that mime-type in the Accept header, UTF-8 is used. Otherwise, the specified charset is used.
  2. If the serialization method has been chosen due to the format parameter or the query file extension the content-type of the response is chosen as follows:
    • JSON-XML-hybrid serialization: the response content type depends on the first item of the result. If it is an XML node the response content-type will be application/xml;charset=UTF-8, otherwise application/json;charset=UTF-8
    • JSON serialization: application/json;charset=UTF-8
    • XML serialization: application/xml;charset=UTF-8
    • Text serialization: text/plain;charset=UTF-8
    • HTML serialization: text/html;charset=UTF-8
    • XHTML serialization: application/xhtml+xml;charset=UTF-8
    • 28.io serialization: application/28io+json;charset=UTF-8

If any of the items produced by the query cannot be serialized using the chosen serialization method a 500 internal server error will be raised.

Enabling trace or query profiling

To debug a query using the trace#2 function, you can specify the trace parameter. Similarly, to profile the execution of a query, you can specify the profile parameter.

Iterator identifiers are not stable, in that, they might change in different calls to this method. Iterator identifiers allow to analyze reference relationships between iterators.

The output of the trace function, or the query profile is serialized to an S3 object. Its location is returned via the X-28msec-Trace or the X-28msec-Profile header, respectively. The object will be available on S3 for at least 1 day after it has been created.

Enabling trace or profiling always requires a token to be specified, even for public queries.

After the response has been returned, a few seconds may be necessary before the trace result can be retrieved from S3.

Binding Query Parameters

External query variables can be annotated such that their values are automatically bound to query parameters, headers, bodies or environment variables, (performing type conversions if necessary). Default values are specified assigning a value to the external variables in their declaration. In case the empty sequence is a valid value for the variable and no default value is specified, we consider the default value to be the empty sequence. In case a variable has no default value and the corresponding query parameter, header or environment variable is not specified by the request an error will be raised and the status code of the response will be set to 400. When a request body is empty, we consider it to be the empty string/base64Binary. The annotations are in the http://www.28msec.com/annotations/rest namespace that is pre-bound to the rest prefix. The following values can be bound to an external variables:

  • Query Parameters. To bind an external variable to the value of a query parameter with a given name you can use the %rest:query(" param-name ") annotation. If the bound query parameter is given more than once, then the variable is bound to a sequence comprising all the values.
    The param-name is optional: if not given, the variable's value is to be bound to the values of the query parameter with the same name as the variable. By default, the parameter name is matched in a case-sensitive manner.
    The entire query annotation is optional since it is the default for external variables.
    For example: 
    declare %rest:query("name") variable $var as xs:string external;
declare %rest:query variable $name as xs:string external;
declare variable $name as xs:string external := "foo";
    would be bound to query parameters named name. The last declaration defines foo as default value, in case the request specified no name query parameter. The following optional annotations are supported:
    • %rest:case-insensitive. If specified, the parameter name is considered case-insensitive. The variables in the previous example would be bound to all the values of the query parameters named name, Name, NAME, or any other combination of upper- and lower-case letters.
    • %rest:distinct. If specified, identical values are coalesced into a single value.
    • %rest:encoding(" encoding "). Specifies the text encoding of a value.
  • Headers. To bind an external variable to the value of an header with a given name you can use the %rest:header(" header-name ") annotation. If the bound header is given more than once, then the variable is bound to a sequence comprising all the values. The header name is matched in a case-insensitive manner.
    The header-name is optional: if not given, the variable's value is to be bound to the HTTP header with the same name as the variable.
    For example: 
    declare %rest:header("content-type") variable $var as xs:string external;
declare %rest:header variable $content-type as xs:string external;
    would be bound to the value of the Content-Type header.
  • Request body. To bind an external variable to the value of an header with a given name you can use the %rest:body-text or the %rest:body-binary annotations. When binding the body as text, the used encoding is the one specified in the request, or ISO-8859-1 if none is specified. To force a specific encoding, the %rest:encoding(" encoding ") annotation can be used. For example: 
    declare %rest:body-text variable $body-text as xs:string external;
declare %rest:body-binary variable $body-binary as xs:base64Binary external;
    would be bound to the body as text (resp. as binary).
  • Environment variables. To bind an external variable to the value of an environment variable with a given name you can use the %rest:env(" env-var-name ") annotation.
    The env-var-name is optional: if not given, the variable's value is to be bound to the variable with the same name as the query variable. Valid variable names are specified in RFC 3875, section 4.1.

parameters.name: query-path
parameters.description: The query path. It starts with public or private and can contain slashes.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The serialization method to use for the results of the executed query. When choosing a serialization method, this parameter has a lower priority than the Accept header.

parameters.name: trace
parameters.description: Whether to enable the output of trace#2.

responseMessages.message: The query produced no results.
Bad request: a parameter is missing or invalid.
Unauthorized: the specified project token is invalid or expired.
The specified query cannot be found.
A side-effecting query cannot be invoked using GET.
An internal error occurred during the processing of the request.

examples.title: Executing a non-side-effecting query
examples.description: The following request executes a public query named hello_world.jq.

operations.notes:
This method executes a query and serialize its results using a chosen serialization method. The following serialization methods are available: JSON-XML-hybrid, JSON, XML, Text, HTML, and XHTML.

It is also possible to use the 28.io serialization method. The 28.io serialization produces a JSON object with metadata about the items produced as query result. This serialization method format is unstable and will be documented as soon we are ready to commit to backward compatibility.

Query Serialization

If the query specifies the response content-type or encoding using the HTTP response module and the query execution completes without raising errors, its serialization method cannot be overridden through this API. Similarly, if the query specifies a response status code and the query execution completes without raising errors, the HTTP status code set by the query is systematically used as the response status code.

If the query does not specify a response content-type, the serialization method can be chosen by means of the Accept header or by specifying the format parameter. In case the query does not specify a response content-type and no serialization method is specified, JSON-XML-hybrid is used.

Specifically, the serialization method is chosen as follows:

  1. if an Accept header is specified and if it contains at least one supported mime-type/charset pair, the serialization method corresponding to the most preferred one (according to the "q" modifier first and the order in which the mime-types are specified second) among those supported is chosen;
  2. otherwise, if a format parameter is specified, the corresponding serialization method is chosen;
  3. otherwise, JSON-XML-hybrid is used.

If the Accept header is specified and it contains at least one supported mime-type, the preferred supported mime-type is used to choose the serialization method, according to the following mapping:

  • application/mixed-json-xml: JSON-XML-hybrid Serialization
  • application/json or any mime-type which ends with +json: JSON Serialization
  • text/xml, application/xml or any mime-type which ends with +xml: XML Serialization
  • text/html: HTML Serialization
  • application/xhtml+xml: XHTML Serialization
  • application/28io+json: 28.io Serialization (format definition unstable)
  • * / *: the Accept header is ignored and the format parameter, if specified, is used to choose the serialization method.

Any mime-type not matching one of the conditions listed above is not supported by this resource.

If the format parameter is used to choose the serialization method, the following mapping is used:

  • .mixed: JSON-XML-hybrid Serialization
  • .json: JSON Serialization
  • .xml: XML Serialization
  • .text: Text Serialization
  • .html: HTML Serialization
  • .xhtml: XHTML Serialization
  • .28io-json: 28.io Serialization (format definition unstable).

Response Content-Type and Encoding

The content-type of the response is determined as follows:

  1. If the query has set the response content-type, it will be used in the response. If this content-type, however, is not acceptable according to the Accept header specified in the request, an error will be raised and the response status code will be set to 406. Note that application/mixed-json-xml is treated as * / * when considering if the content-type set by the query is accepted or not.
  2. If the serialization method has been chosen depending on one of the mime-types specified in the Accept header, the following criterion are used:
    • if the used mime-type is * / * or application/mixed-json-xml then the response content type depends on the first item of the result. If it is an XML node the response content-type will be application/xml, otherwise application/json
    • for any other mime-type, the same mime-type is used in the response.
    In case no charset has been set by the query or specified for that mime-type in the Accept header, UTF-8 is used.
  3. If the serialization method has been chosen due to the format parameter or the query file extension the content-type of the response is chosen as follows:
    • JSON-XML-hybrid serialization: the response content type depends on the first item of the result. If it is an XML node the response content-type will be application/xml;charset=UTF-8, otherwise application/json;charset=UTF-8
    • JSON serialization: application/json;charset=UTF-8
    • XML serialization: application/xml;charset=UTF-8
    • Text serialization: text/plain;charset=UTF-8
    • HTML serialization: text/html;charset=UTF-8
    • XHTML serialization: application/xhtml+xml;charset=UTF-8
    • 28.io serialization: application/28io+json;charset=UTF-8

If the items produced by the query cannot be serialized using the chosen serialization method a 500 internal server error will be raised.

Asynchronous execution

To execute the query asynchronously, you can specify the async parameter. To run a query asynchronously a default MongoDB database must be configured. The asynchronously executed query and its results can then be managed through the _jobs API using the URL returned in the location header. Optionally you can specify the output collection throught the output-collection parameter. When running a query asynchronously any serialization options will be ignored. Serialization options can be specified when retrieving the query results through the _jobs API.

Enabling trace or query profiling

To debug a query using the trace#2 function, you can specify the trace parameter. Similarly, to profile the execution of a query, you can specify the profile parameter.

Iterator identifiers are not stable, in that, they might change in different calls to this method. Iterator identifiers allow to analyze reference relationships between iterators.

The output of the trace function, or the query profile is serialized to an S3 object. Its location is returned via the X-28msec-Trace or the X-28msec-Profile header, respectively. The object will be available on S3 for at least 1 day after it has been created.

Enabling trace or profiling always requires a token to be specified, even for public queries.

After the response has been returned, a few seconds may be necessary before the trace result can be retrieved from S3.

Binding Query Parameters

External query variables can be annotated such that their values are automatically bound to query parameters, headers, bodies or environment variables, (performing type conversions if necessary). Default values are specified assigning a value to the external variables in their declaration. In case the empty sequence is a valid value for the variable and no default value is specified, we consider the default value to be the empty sequence.In case a variable has no default value and the corresponding query parameter, header or environment variable is not specified by the request an error will be raised and the status code of the response will be set to 400. When a request body is empty, we consider it to be the empty string/base64Binary. The annotations are in the http://www.28msec.com/annotations/rest namespace that is pre-bound to the rest prefix. The following values can be bound to an external variables:

  • Query Parameters. To bind an external variable to the value of a query parameter with a given name you can use the %rest:query(" param-name ") annotation. If the bound query parameter is given more than once, then the variable is bound to a sequence comprising all the values.
    The param-name is optional: if not given, the variable's value is to be bound to the values of the query parameter with the same name as the variable. By default, the parameter name is matched in a case-sensitive manner.
    The entire query annotation is optional since it is the default for external variables.
    For example: 
    declare %rest:query("name") variable $var as xs:string external;
declare %rest:query variable $name as xs:string external;
declare variable $name as xs:string external := "foo";
    would be bound to query parameters named name. The last declaration defines foo as default value, in case the request specified no name query parameter. The following optional annotations are supported:
    • %rest:case-insensitive. If specified, the parameter name is considered case-insensitive. The variables in the previous example would be bound to all the values of the query parameters named name, Name, NAME, or any other combination of upper- and lower-case letters.
    • %rest:distinct. If specified, identical values are coalesced into a single value.
    • %rest:encoding(" encoding "). Specifies the text encoding of a value.
  • Headers. To bind an external variable to the value of an header with a given name you can use the %rest:header(" header-name ") annotation. If the bound header is given more than once, then the variable is bound to a sequence comprising all the values. The header name is matched in a case-insensitive manner.
    The header-name is optional: if not given, the variable's value is to be bound to the HTTP header with the same name as the variable.
    For example: 
    declare %rest:header("content-type") variable $var as xs:string external;
declare %rest:header variable $content-type as xs:string external;
    would be bound to the value of the Content-Type header.
  • Request body. To bind an external variable to the value of an header with a given name you can use the %rest:body-text or the %rest:body-binary annotations. When binding the body as text, the used encoding is the one specified in the request, or ISO-8859-1 if none is specified. To force a specific encoding, the %rest:encoding(" encoding ") annotation can be used. For example: 
    declare %rest:body-text variable $body-text as xs:string external;
declare %rest:body-binary variable $body-binary as xs:base64Binary external;
    would be bound to the body as text (resp. as binary).
  • Environment variables. To bind an external variable to the value of an environment variable with a given name you can use the %rest:env(" env-var-name ") annotation.
    The env-var-name is optional: if not given, the variable's value is to be bound to the variable with the same name as the query variable. Valid variable names are specified in RFC 3875, section 4.1.

parameters.name: query-path
parameters.description: The query path. It starts with public or private and can contain slashes.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: The serialization method to use for the results of the executed query. When choosing a serialization method, this parameter has a lower priority than the Accept header.

parameters.name: async
parameters.description: Whether to execute the query asynchronously or not.

parameters.name: output-collection
parameters.description: The output collection when runnng the query asynchronously.

parameters.name: trace
parameters.description: Whether to enable the output trace#2.

The content-type or charset set by the query is not accepted according to the request Accept header. Note that application/mixed-json-xml is treated as */* when determining if the content-type set by the query is accepted or not.
The request specified to run the query asynchronously but no default MongoDB database has been configured.

operations.notes: This method retrieves the source code of a query. The response content-type is set according to the query language. If the query does not declare its own dialect, the query file extension is used to infer the language of the query. If the query file extension is .xq the query language is considered to be XQuery, JSONiq, otherwise.

parameters.description: The query path. It starts with "public" or "private" and contains slashes.

examples.title: Retrieving a query source code
examples.description: The following request retrieves the source code a public query named hello_world.jq.

operations.notes:
This method creates a new query resource. If the compile option is none, the query will not be compiled, if it is lax it will be compiled and any potential compilation error reported. In this case, compilation errors will not prevent the query to be created. To only create the query if no compilation errors are present, set the compile option to strict. The default is none.

The query file extension must be either .jq or .xq.

parameters.name: query-path
parameters.description: The query path. It starts with "public" or "private" and contains slashes.

parameters.name: compile
parameters.description: The kind of compilation to perform. The default is none.

parameters.name: query-body
parameters.description: The source code of the query

responseMessages.message: Bad request: a parameter is missing or invalid.
Unauthorized: the specified project token is invalid or expired.
A compilation error occurred in strict mode.
An internal error occurred during the processing of the request.

examples.title: Creating a new query
examples.description: The following request creates a public query named hello_world.jq.

operations.notes:
This method updates the source code of an existing query. If the compile option is none, the query will not be compiled, if it is lax it will be compiled and any potential compilation error reported. In this case, compilation errors will not prevent the query to be created or updated. To only create the query if no compilation errors are present, set the compile option to strict. The default is none.

The query file extension must be either .jq or .xq.

parameters.description: The kind of compilation to perform. The default is none.

request_id.description: The request identifier. Present only if the compilation fails

context.description: The complete domain name of the project

message.description: A formatted string which contain the error code (always) and the module name, line and column-number and error description (when available)

type.description: For XQuery errors, the type of the error (e.g. static)

code.description: For XQuery errors, the error code

location.description: For XQuery errors, the error location (if available)

stack-trace.description: For XQuery errors, the error stack trace (if available)

context.description: The complete domain name of the project

message.description: A formatted string which contain the error code (always) and the module name, line and column-number and error description (when available)

type.description: For XQuery errors, the type of the error (e.g. static)

code.description: For XQuery errors, the error code

location.description: For XQuery errors, the error location (if available)

ModuleUpdate.description: The result of the module compilation

compilationError.description: The compilation error occurred during the module compilation, if any

QueryListing.description: A list of public and/or private queries

public.description: The list of public queries. It is always present when listing all queries or public queries

private.description: The list of public queries. It is always present when listing all queries or private queries

QueryResult28IO.description: Query results serialized using the 28io+json serialization method

defaultContentType.description: The default content-type. All serialized items that do not contains a "content_type" field have this content-type

Item28IO.description: An item serialized using the 28io+json serialization method

contentType.description: The item content-type, if different from the default one

href.description: A link that can be used to refer to the item. It is present only for items which are stored in a MongoDB collection

content.description: The item serialized using the "json+xml hybrid" serialization method

lastModified.description: The date and time the query was last modified
